ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I developed an increased capacity for thinking about medical topics using the Spanish language.
I learned about a lot of medical topics in Spanish, many of which I hadn't even learned about in English previously.
improved spanish skills
I became more fluent in spanish conversation, listening, reading and writing.
I gained greater familiarity with Spanish medical vocabulary.
I learned about how to describe diseases and physiologies in Spanish.

Learned about the medical system in Hispanic countries. Emphasis placed on exposure to different physiological diseases (diabetes, cancer, osteoporosis, etc.) and the social disparities and health determinants that accompany them. Developed Spanish-speaking skills through oral participation.
Practice speaking, reading, and writing in Spanish. Learned some medical vocabulary in Spanish.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: The class was well taught and engaging, although the homeworks were slightly tedious and it was somewhat annoying to have to print everything out rather than submit on Canvas.
I thought the course was ran well
Strengths: The professor was very kind and helpful! Weaknesses: Some weekly assignments were much longer than others, which made it hard to plan at times.

I think it is nice that the course goes over various common diseases, but I thought we would model talking to patients more and how to translate important visits. I wish we talked more about ethical concepts, but it was super helpful to learn about particular diseases and how to use Spanish to describe them.

Strengths: highly interactive (oral participation and write homework responses), collaborative, relatively low workload.
Areas for Improvement: sometimes received minimal feedback on written assignments.

Strengths: The homework assignments were good writing practice and a reasonable amount of weekly work. Class was relaxed and a welcoming environment to participate in. I enjoyed putting together the group presentations as well.

Weaknesses: I would have been happy to do another group presentation. I think that would be a good way to ensure all students are participating and practicing speaking in Spanish

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: I would definitely recommend this course to another student who is looking to improve their Spanish proficiency and is comfortable discussing potentially sensitive medical topics.
I would 100% recommend this course because it was an engaging way to learn about health topics in Spanish at a high level
yes, its a great opportunity to improve your spanish

I think many should take this course even if "medical" terminology may not be your thing. You truly do learn a lot more than just medical terms, and you learn a lot about social norms, cultural aspects, and you get a lot of practice of speaking and understanding spanish.
Yes, if they are interested in Spanish and/or Medicine
Yes! As someone going into healthcare, I feel that I am much better prepared having taken this class.

Yes, I would! Professor Carreras is so kind and class can be very cute and fun. I think sometimes it could get boring during lecture time but the oral presentations were engaging at the end of the course and the course is amazing for a Spanish L5!

I would highly recommend this course to any student regardless of their major/academic background. It is a wonderful opportunity to practice your Spanish in an encouraging setting and learn about health conditions and social determinants that affect global communities. The content is applicable to approaching health outcomes from a multicultural perspective in the New Haven community.
Maybe. If you are looking for a 5th class to add, this one is pretty relaxed. The weekly assignments are very fair and manageable, although expect to put aside a few hours to complete them.
